text.p: These are the highlights in the Bosnian press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- High representative in Bosnia Carlos Westendorp urges the Bosnian Council of Ministers to harmonise their positions after they failed to adopt a law on citizenship and passports during Thursday's session.
- High Representative in Bosnia called the laws on citizenship, passports and opening of the three Bosnian airports for civilian traffic the gravest issues at the moment.

- The international community is getting very tired of the lack of commitment to the peace process shown by those who claim to represent the people of this country, says the spokesman of the office of High Representative.

- The Moslem-Croat federation parliament's House of Representatives decided to form a committee to investigate the validity of British Foreign Secretary's accusations on alleged corruption of Bosnia's administration.
- The Moslem leading Party of Democratic Action (SDA) says British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook was a "victim of misinformation".
- There has been no malversation or abuse of funds and equipment that go through the World Bank says Saumya Mitra, deputy director to the World Bank Mission in Sarajevo.

- The president of the Bosnian Trade Union, Sulejman Hrle, at a meeting with International Labour Organisation coordinator for Bosnia Herbert Schmidt, said Moslem and Croat workers in Bosnia's Serb entity and Moslems and Serbs in so-called Herzeg-Bosnia are being fired because of their ethnic origin.
- The International Labour Organisation will insist on the application of an ILO convention which prohibits the dismissal of workers on the basis of their nationality.
